> value to those runners?
>

My use of JUnit is pretty simplistic. I've been using it for about 6
months now. I just use the junit.textui TestRunner. I create my
TestSuites by hand. All my test suites follow the same basic pattern, I
know I'm asking for trouble by posting code but here it is:

public class TestAll extends TestCase
{
public TestAll(java.lang.String testName)
{
super(testName);
}

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
{
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
System.exit(0);
}

public static Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("All Tests");
suite.addTest(TestParser.suite());
suite.addTest(TestPart.suite());
suite.addTest(TestManager.suite());
suite.addTest(TestData.suite());
suite.addTest(TestJob.suite());
suite.addTest(TestServer.suite());
suite.addTest(TestStatus.suite());
return suite;
}
}

This has been working well for me, but I haven't really needed to change
suites once I create them. The only way they might change is when I add
or remove a test. If one test fails that causes other tests to fail
then I just look at the first failing test and fix the problem, then run
the tests again. I still have a lot to learn about JUnit and unit
testing in general so I may be doing things completely different 6
months from now...

Kris
